descendants.content:
@adron @ClimateNewsNow @Lizbon A *slight* caveat of this research is that the catalyst that does the breaking down is CdS nanocrystals. Cadmium is a heavy metal, and cadmium sulfide is both toxic and carcinogenic. For these reasons, cadmium has been banned from industrial applications (mostly in electronics) in most of the world for a while now.

Making nanocrystals out of it and then somehow making sure those never make it out of the treatment process sounds like an engineering nightmare to me.

account.note: I am doing #electronics, #embedded programming, #python scripting, hardware security and recently some sewing. Pronouns: er/they

descendants.content: @jaseg @adron @ClimateNewsNow @Lizbon Out of one frying pan and into the next. Still, the toxicity of cadmium can at least be contained, as opposed to chemicals with an absurdly long half-life that are everywhere and otherwise cannot be easily destroyed.

descendants.content:
@ClimateNewsNow

> The technique broke down 100% of *certain types of* these pollutants

60% of the time, it works every time!

(Yes, I get what it's saying, but that first line is definitely overselling the result, which is IMO poor science communication.)

@ClimateNewsNow

A matter of breaking down the long polymer chains and that can be done with electromagnetic radiation (light)…generically true for a lot of plastics btw…

account.note:
XFEL crystallography data processing methods developer. I use my degree in chemistry to write software to use physics to understand biology.

70% coffee by volume. I’m really into electronics and 3d printing right now. I have a very fluffy and affectionate cat. Big fan of bicycles and trains, better public infrastructure generally, and investment in collective wellbeing generally. Food motivated; very easily bribed with coffee and pastries. Always learning.

descendants.content:
@Herman @ClimateNewsNow At least the European Union works for a PFAS-ban: https://echa.europa.eu/hot-topics/perfluoroalkyl-chemicals-pfas - in some countries they already prepared partial bans.
The problem is PFAS in our soils (especially agricultural ones), in oceans. We can't put nano-particles, Cadmium etc. into ecological systems.
This news will *perhaps* help the industry who want's to produce more and recycling their waste in closed tanks.

descendants.content:
@ClimateNewsNow Sounds like a sensation but if that should ever work on a sufficiently large enough scale in the laboratory, this does not help against the global pollution we have. PFAS is deep in the soils, in the oceans, etc. Imagine this temperature in Arctic regions! In this respect, the article is very clickbait not science journalism.
The original study is less "rose-red": https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/anie.202408687

account.note:
I'm a simple and compassionate Citizen of the Earth.

And have been online almost since the internet began with one hope, and message of it.

Most of the things I post are from a personal book of observations on humanity I've been compiling since I was 14, titled "Wisdom, Warning, and Tyranny." With some from a plan to assure and forward humanity titled "A Future of the Brave."

But please be warned that internet searches for me and "Wisdom, Warning, and Tyranny", or "A Future of the Brave" are often misdirected to other, possibly dangerous, websites. And the links are often very sophisticated, even including some of my most popular observations in the results.

I understand that's odd, and given that I'm really no one I'm just as surprised as you.

In any case my old website, and "A Future of the Brave", are found at the most obvious address - http://www.searingtruth.com

Please don't follow any other links unless you know where they lead.
